comment.text: Looks ok for me. Runs since it was ready in koji. Works on baremetal (non UEFI mode) AMD Ryzen5 3600, Mainboard MSI B450M Mortar Max with prop. nvidia driver from rpmfusion.org (GTX980 card). Works with Gnome-Desktop (Xorg). Regression test passed (paxtest, selinux-dac-controls and libhugetlbfs skipped).
default & performance tests pass (KVM)
default & performance tests pass (KVM)
Works fine on AMD desktop w/nvidia.
Works for me and commit 8e3341257e3b5774ec8cd3ef1ba0c0d3fada322b (finally) fixed the boltd crashes I had experienced with all the previous releases of kernel 5.13

Works for me.. been up all day with no issues noticed.  
The enabled Default and Performance tests pass OK. AMD 965, x86_64 work station, SSD's > RAID1. Plasma DE from Zawertun's COPR, X-org, nVidia GTX 650 (GK107) nVidia RPM's from RPMFusion (470.63.01)

Passed both test suites.
Tested on a VM.

works for me in virtualbox 6.1.26, also works fine on my home desktop and the laptop as well. Have been running since build (got the rpms directly from koji as soon as the build finished). I can see 5.13.11 is out now though at kernel.org

All tests passed Fedora 33 Mate on Acer NITRO 5 AN515-54-574Q 
Intel(R) Core(TM) i5-9300H CPU @ 2.40GHz (8) @ 4.100GHz
GPU: Intel UHD Graphics CoffeeLake-H GT2 [UHD Graphics 630] 
GPU: NVIDIA Model: TU117M GeForce GTX 1650 Mobile / Max-Q
on Lenovo Ideapad 330, "suspend" doesn't work properly after updating to this kernel version, so when laptop is "suspended", laptop can't be restarted.

bugs.title: CVE-2021-38166 kernel: integer overflow and out-of-bounds write in kernel/bpf/hashtab.c when many elements are placed in a single bucket

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2021-38166 kernel: integer overflow and out-of-bounds write in kernel/bpf/hashtab.c when many elements are placed in a single bucket

long_desc.thetext:
A flaw in the Linux kernels bpf implementation allows a local attacker to create an integer overflow resulting in an out-of-bounds write when a hashtable bucket has too many elements inserted.  This is limited to users who are able to use the bpf syscall, and is not enabeled by default on Red Hat Enterprise Linux kernels.

By default there is no action required, if the system has been configured to allow for unprivileged users to use the ebpf subsystem this can be rectified by issuing the command:

# sysctl -w kernel.unprivileged_bpf_disabled=1

To make these changes persistent between boots, insert the same rule using the mechanisms outlined in the man pages for sysctl.d and sysctl.conf


Reference and upstream patch:
https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/bpf/bpf.git/commit/?id=c4eb1f403243fc7bbb7de644db8587c03de36da6

Created kernel tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 1993191]

This is limited to users who are able to use the bpf syscall, and is not enabeled by default on Red Hat Enterprise Linux kernels.

Created kernel tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 1993191]

This is an automatically created tracking bug!  It was created to ensure
that one or more security vulnerabilities are fixed in affected versions
of fedora-all.

For comments that are specific to the vulnerability please use bugs filed
against the "Security Response" product referenced in the "Blocks" field.

For more information see:
http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Security/TrackingBugs

When submitting as an update, use the fedpkg template provided in the next
comment(s).  This will include the bug IDs of this tracking bug as well as
the relevant top-level CVE bugs.

Please also mention the CVE IDs being fixed in the RPM changelog and the
fedpkg commit message.

NOTE: this issue affects multiple supported versions of Fedora. While only
one tracking bug has been filed, please correct all affected versions at
the same time.  If you need to fix the versions independent of each other,
you may clone this bug as appropriate.

Reproducers, if any, will remain confidential and never be made public, unless done so by the security team.

Use the following template to for the 'fedpkg update' request to submit an
update for this issue as it contains the top-level parent bug(s) as well as
this tracking bug.  This will ensure that all associated bugs get updated
when new packages are pushed to stable.

=====

# bugfix, security, enhancement, newpackage (required)
type=security

# low, medium, high, urgent (required)
severity=high

# testing, stable
request=testing

# Bug numbers: 1234,9876
bugs=1993190,1993191

# Description of your update
notes=Security fix for [PUT CVEs HERE]

# Enable request automation based on the stable/unstable karma thresholds
autokarma=True
stable_karma=3
unstable_karma=-3

# Automatically close bugs when this marked as stable
close_bugs=True

# Suggest that users restart after update
suggest_reboot=False

======

Additionally, you may opt to use the bodhi web interface to submit updates:

https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/new
FEDORA-2021-b22606e88b has been submitted as an update to Fedora 33. https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/FEDORA-2021-b22606e88b
FEDORA-2021-f35f45a76f has been submitted as an update to Fedora 34. https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/FEDORA-2021-f35f45a76f

FEDORA-2021-f35f45a76f has been pushed to the Fedora 34 testing repository.
Soon you'll be able to install the update with the following command:
`sudo dnf upgrade --enablerepo=updates-testing --advisory=FEDORA-2021-f35f45a76f`
You can provide feedback for this update here: https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/FEDORA-2021-f35f45a76f

See also https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/QA:Updates_Testing for more information on how to test updates.

FEDORA-2021-b22606e88b has been pushed to the Fedora 33 testing repository.
Soon you'll be able to install the update with the following command:
`sudo dnf upgrade --enablerepo=updates-testing --advisory=FEDORA-2021-b22606e88b`
You can provide feedback for this update here: https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/FEDORA-2021-b22606e88b

See also https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/QA:Updates_Testing for more information on how to test updates.

FEDORA-2021-f35f45a76f has been pushed to the Fedora 34 stable repository.
If problem still persists, please make note of it in this bug report.

FEDORA-2021-b22606e88b has been pushed to the Fedora 33 stable repository.
If problem still persists, please make note of it in this bug report.
